overview: This measure appropriates funds for the Judiciary for the 2025–2027 biennium. [4] Operating resource requests center around funding to make permanent or expand three Specialty Courts on O‘ahu, to fully staff the new Wahiawā District Court, an additional District Court Judge in Kona, cybersecurity costs, funding for the Criminal Justice Research Institute, and restoration of funding for essential staffing. [4] [4] The purpose of this measure is to appropriate funds for the operating and capital improvement costs of the Judiciary Branch for fiscal biennium 2025-2027. [6]
appropriations: The Judiciary requests additional operating resources in the amount of $6.17M in FY 2026, and $6.25M in FY 2027. [4] [4] This measure, as amended, appropriates $11,900,000 (HB400_HD1_HSCR1171_.PDF.txt) in General Obligation Bonds for Capital Improvements for FY 2025-2026. [6] The legislative document specifies the total sum of general obligation bonds issued shall not exceed $11,900,000 (HB400_HD1_.HTM.txt). [CHUNK_192, NUMBER_123]
assumptions_and_methodology: The Judiciary's resource requirements are based on current circumstances and projected resource needs for the future. [4] The request for additional operating resources constitutes an addition of approximately 3% to the Judiciary’s operating budget. [4] The increased request for capital improvement bond funds is due to new information that the relocation of the Children’s Justice Center on O‘ahu will require at least $2M (from testimony) more than previously appropriated. [CHUNK_5, CHUNK_6, NUMBER_114, NUMBER_115]
agency_impact: The Judiciary requests additional operating resources in the amount of 17.0 permanent FTE and 1.0 temporary FTE. [4] Nine of the 18 requested positions are to continue current staffing, as seven temporary positions for the Women’s Court Pilot Project and two positions for the CJRI are set to expire. [4] The remaining requested positions will significantly expand capacity to certain operations, such as adding a new District Court Judge in Kona and fully staffing the new Wahiawā District Court. [4] [4] [4]
economic_impact: The Women’s Court program aims to aid participants in bettering their economic conditions and life circumstances as an alternative to incarceration. [4] The Driving While Impaired (DWI) Court Program seeks to reduce recidivism among repeat and high-risk offenders, which may reduce public safety costs. [4] [4] This measure also provides critical funding for civil legal services to low- and moderate-income individuals in Hawai‘i. [4]
policy_impact: This measure will establish a permanent Women’s Court, as the three-year pilot project is set to expire at the end of FY 2025. [4] [4] It also seeks to make the Driving While Impaired (DWI) Court Program permanent, which was initially supported by federal funding. [4] [4] The bill continues resources for the Criminal Justice Research Institute (CJRI), established by Act 179 (SLH 2019), and restores funding for positions that were defunded during the early part of the COVID-19 pandemic. [4] [4]
revenue_sources: The appropriations in this measure are primarily from general funds and general obligation bond funds. [5] The legislative document authorizes the issuance of general obligation bonds not to exceed $11,900,000 (HB400_HD1_.HTM.txt) to finance capital improvement projects. operating_revenue_impact: The Judiciary remains vigilant during a period of uncertainty over federal funding and its possible impact on budgets and operations. [4] Testimony notes that there have been dramatic reductions in available federal funds for victims of crime and domestic-violence survivors. [4] The documents do not identify any new sources of operating revenue resulting from this measure. [4]
